response.answer_text: Active Study vs. Passive StudyBe actively involved in managing the learning process, the mathematics and your study time: Take responsibility for studying, recognizing what you do and don't know, and knowing how to get your Instructor to help you with what you don't know.Attend class every day and take complete notes. Instructors formulate test questions based on material and examples covered in class as well as on those in the text.Be an active participant in the classroom. Get ahead in the book; try to work some of the problems before they are covered in class. Anticipate what the Instructor's next step will be.Ask questions in class! There are usually other students wanting to know the answers to the same questions you have.Go to office hours and ask questions. The Instructor will be pleased to see that you are interested, and you will be actively helping yourself.Good study habits throughout the semester make it easier to study for tests. http://...Studying Math is Different from Studying Other Subjects Math is learned by doing problems. Do the homework. The problems help you learn the formulas and techniques you do need to know, as well as improve your problem-solving prowess.A word of warning: Each class builds on the previous ones, all semester long. You must keep up with the Instructor: attend class, read the text and do homework every day. Falling a day behind puts you at a disadvantage. Falling a week behind puts you in deep trouble.A word of encouragement: Each class builds on the previous ones, all semester long. You're always reviewing previous material as you do new material. Many of the ideas hang together. Identifying and learning the key concepts means you don't have to memorize as much. http://...College Math is Different from High School MathA College math class meets less often and covers material at about twice the pace that a High School course does. You are expected to absorb new material much more quickly. Tests are probably spaced farther apart and so cover more material than before. The Instructor may not even check your homework. Take responsibility for keeping up with the homework. Make sure you find out how to do it.You probably need to spend more time studying per week - you do more of the learning outside of class than in High School.Tests may seem harder just because they cover more material. http://...Study TimeYou may know a rule of thumb about math (and other) classes: at least 2 hours of study time per class hour. But this may not be enough! Take as much time as you need to do all the homework and to get complete understanding of the material.Form a study group. Meet once or twice a week (also use the phone). Go over problems you've had trouble with. Either someone else in the group will help you, or you will discover you're all stuck on the same problems. Then it's time to get help from your Instructor.The more challenging the material, the more time you should spend on it.http://...Problem Solvinghttp://...Problem Solving (Homework and Tests) The higher the math class, the more types of problems: in earlier classes, problems often required just one step to find a solution. Increasingly, you will tackle problems which require several steps to solve them. Break these problems down into smaller pieces and solve each piece - divide and conquer!Problem types:Problems testing memorization ("drill"),Problems testing skills ("drill"),Problems requiring application of skills to familiar situations ("template" problems),Problems requiring application of skills to unfamiliar situations (you develop a strategy for a new problem type),Problems requiring that you extend the skills or theory you know before applying them to an unfamiliar situation.In early courses, you solved problems of types 1, 2 and 3. By College Algebra you expect to do mostly problems of types 2 and 3 and sometimes of type 4. Later courses expect you to tackle more and more problems of types 3 and 4, and (eventually) of type 5. Each problem of types 4 or 5 usually requires you to use a multi-step approach, and may involve several different math skills and techniques.When you work problems on homework, write out complete solutions, as if you were taking a test. Don't just scratch out a few lines and check the answer in the back of the book. If your answer is not right, rework the problem; don't just do some mental gymnastics to convince yourself that you could get the correct answer. If you can't get the answer, get help.The practice you get doing homework and reviewing will make test problems easier to tackle. http://...Tips on Problem Solving Apply Pólya's four-step process:The first and most important step in solving a problem is to understand the problem, that is, identify exactly which quantity the problem is asking you to find or solve for (make sure you read the whole problem).Next you need to devise a plan, that is, identify which skills and techniques you have learned can be applied to solve the problem at hand.Carry out the plan.Look back: Does the answer you found seem reasonable? Also review the problem and method of solution so that you will be able to more easily recognize and solve a similar problem.Some problem-solving strategies: use one or more variables, complete a table, consider a special case, look for a pattern, guess and test, draw a picture or diagram, make a list, solve a simpler related problem, use reasoning, work backward, solve an equation, look for a formula, use coordinates. http://..."Word" Problems are Really "Applied" ProblemsThe term "word problem" has only negative connotations. It's better to think of them as "applied problems". These problems should be the most interesting ones to solve. Sometimes the "applied" problems don't appear very realistic, but that's usually because the corresponding real applied problems are too hard or complicated to solve at your current level. But at least you get an idea of how the math you are learning can help solve actual real-world problems. http://...Solving an Applied Problem First convert the problem into mathematics. This step is (usually) the most challenging part of an applied problem. If possible, start by drawing a picture. Label it with all the quantities mentioned in the problem. If a quantity in the problem is not a fixed number, name it by a variable. Identify the goal of the problem. Then complete the conversion of the problem into math, i.e., find equations which describe relationships among the variables, and describe the goal of the problem mathematically.Solve the math problem you have generated, using whatever skills and techniques you need (refer to the four-step process above).As a final step, you should convert the answer of your math problem back into words, so that you have now solved the original applied problem.For Further Reading:George Pólya, How to Solve It,Princeton University Press, Princeton (1945)http://...Studying for a Math Testhttp://...Everyday Study is a Big Part of Test PreparationGood study habits throughout the semester make it easier to study for tests. Do the homework when it is assigned. You cannot hope to cram 3 or 4 weeks worth of learning into a couple of days of study.On tests you have to solve problems; homework problems are the only way to get practice. As you do homework, make lists of formulas and techniques to use later when you study for tests.Ask your Instructor questions as they arise; don't wait until the day or two before a test. The questions you ask right before a test should be to clear up minor details. http://...Studying for a TestStart by going over each section, reviewing your notes and checking that you can still do the homework problems (actually work the problems again). Use the worked examples in the text and notes - cover up the solutions and work the problems yourself. Check your work against the solutions given. You're not ready yet! In the book each problem appears at the end of the section in which you learned how do to that problem; on a test the problems from different sections are all together. Step back and ask yourself what kind of problems you have learned how to solve, what techniques of solution you have learned, and how to tell which techniques go with which problems.Try to explain out loud, in your own words, how each solution strategy is used (e.g. how to solve a quadratic equation). If you get confused during a test, you can mentally return to your verbal "capsule instructions". Check your verbal explanations with a friend during a study session (it's more fun than talking to yourself!).Put yourself in a test-like situation: work problems from review sections at the end of chapters, and work old tests if you can find some. It's important to keep working problems the whole time you're studying.Also: Start studying early. Several days to a week before the test (longer for the final), begin to allot time in your schedule to reviewing for the test.Get lots of sleep the night before the test. Math tests are easier when you are mentally sharp.http://...Taking a Math Testhttp://...Test-Taking Strategy MattersJust as it is important to think about how you spend your study time (in addition to actually doing the studying), it is important to think about what strategies you will use when you take a test (in addition to actually doing the problems on the test). Good test-taking strategy can make a big difference to your grade! http://...Taking a Test First look over the entire test. You'll get a sense of its length. Try to identify those problems you definitely know how to do right away, and those you expect to have to think about.Do the problems in the order that suits you! Start with the problems that you know for sure you can do. This builds confidence and means you don't miss any sure points just because you run out of time. Then try the problems you think you can figure out; then finally try the ones you are least sure about.Time is of the essence - work as quickly and continuously as you can while still writing legibly and showing all your work. If you get stuck on a problem, move on to another one - you can come back later.Work by the clock. On a 50 minute, 100 point test, you have about 5 minutes for a 10 point question. Starting with the easy questions will probably put you ahead of the clock. When you work on a harder problem, spend the allotted time (e.g., 5 minutes) on that question, and if you have not almost finished it, go on to another problem. Do not spend 20 minutes on a problem which will yield few or no points when there are other problems still to try.Show all your work: make it as easy as possible for the Instructor to see how much you do know. Try to write a well-reasoned solution. If your answer is incorrect, the Instructor will assign partial credit based on the work you show.Never waste time erasing! Just draw a line through the work you want ignored and move on. Not only does erasing waste precious time, but you may discover later that you erased something useful (and/or maybe worth partial credit if you cannot complete the problem). You are (usually) not required to fit your answer in the space provided - you can put your answer on another sheet to avoid needing to erase.In a multiple-step problem outline the steps before actually working the problem.Don't give up on a several-part problem just because you can't do the first part. Attempt the other part(s) - if the actual solution depends on the first part, at least explain how you would do it.Make sure you read the questions carefully, and do all parts of each problem.Verify your answers - does each answer make sense given the context of the problem?If you finish early, check every problem (that means rework everything from scratch).http://...Getting Assistancehttp://...WhenGet help as soon as you need it. Don't wait until a test is near. The new material builds on the previous sections, so anything you don't understand now will make future material difficult to understand. http://...Use the Resources You Have Available Ask questions in class. You get help and stay actively involved in the class.Visit the Instructor's Office Hours. Instructors like to see students who want to help themselves.Ask friends, members of your study group, or anyone else who can help. The classmate who explains something to you learns just as much as you do, for he/she must think carefully about how to explain the particular concept or solution in a clear way. So don't be reluctant to ask a classmate.Go to the Math Help Sessions or other tutoring sessions on campus.Find a private tutor if you can't get enough help from other sources.All students need help at some point, so be sure to get the help you need. http://...Asking QuestionsDon't be afraid to ask questions. Any question is better than no question at all (at least your Instructor/tutor will know you are confused). But a good question will allow your helper to quickly identify exactly what you don't understand. Not too helpful comment: "I don't understand this section." The best you can expect in reply to such a remark is a brief review of the section, and this will likely overlook the particular thing(s) which you don't understand.Good comment: "I don't understand why f(x + h) doesn't equal f(x) + f(h)." This is a very specific remark that will get a very specific response and hopefully clear up your difficulty.Good question: "How can you tell the difference between the equation of a circle and the equation of a line?"Okay question: "How do you do #17?"Better question: "Can you show me how to set up #17?" (the Instructor can let you try to finish the problem on your own), or "This is how I tried to do #17. What went wrong?" The focus of attention is onyour thought process.Right after you get help with a problem, work another similar problem by yourself. http://...You Control the Help You GetHelpers should be coaches, not crutches. They should encourage you, give you hints as you need them, and sometimes show you how to do problems. But they should not, nor be expected to, actually do the work you need to do. They are there to help you figure out how to learn math for yourself. When you go to office hours, your study group or a tutor, have a specific list of questions prepared in advance. You should run the session as much as possible.Do not allow yourself to become dependent on a tutor. The tutor cannot take the exams for you. You must take care to be the one in control of tutoring sessions.You must recognize that sometimes you do need some coaching to help you through, and it is up to you to seek out that coaching.

1) If you don't understand something, focus on mastering that topic before moving on to the next topic~It sounds simple, but it is absolutely essential. Lets say a student is learning Algebra, for example. Further, lets say he or she is having a hard time understanding how to add and subtract negative and positive numbers. All of us struggle with this in the beginning as it is a sticky point for most students. Some students in this situation, out of frustration that they "can't" learn this topic, will move on to the next lesson in the hope that they will be able to understand that one.This is a recipe for disaster.Math is very much like learning to read. If you don't know your letter sounds then you have no hope of being able to sound out words of course there is no way possible that you could read a book. All math courses are taught in a specific sequence because the every topic builds on the previous topic. If you are having a problem with a topic, continue working with that one until you understand it and can work problems successfully. Watch the DVD section over again, attend tutoring, read the book and examples a second time, or even get a totally different book to have it explained a different way...but whatever you do not turn the page and tackle the next topic. If you do, you will get even more frustrated and you in all likelihood will begin to give up hope.2)Work example problems and check your answers to gain practice with every lesson~The entire premise of the DVD series is to "learn by example" and it is quite simply the easiest way to learn Math. After watching the section on the DVD and reading the section in your textbook, begin working examples from the end of the chapter. Make sure to work the problems that have answers in the back of the book, and check every one. Always begin with the easiest problem in your book, even if you think it will be too "easy" to solve. It is very very important to build your confidence. This is why the DVD lessons begin with easier problems that no one will have any issue understanding. Gradually work harder and harder problems from your book and check your answer for each one. After working a dozen or more problems from the section (two dozen is best), you are ready to move on to the next section. Many students want to plow though a lesson just to make it to the next one. You cannot just read a section in a Math book and become an expert on that section. You must work problems. If you can't work problems then you are not ready to move on. The good news is that working problems will build your confidence, and confidence is 100% the name of the game in Math.3)When beginning to work a Math problem, do not "map out a path from problem-to-answer" in your head before writing anything down~I see this almost every day. It is very common when someone looks at a Math problem that they try to "figure it out" in their head before writing anything down. Take Algebra for example. When a beginning student looks at an equation, he or she will be tempted to solve the equation in their head and not write anything down. Students are tempted to do this most often with Word Problems. Since a word problem is written in sentence form, it is common to think that you can "think your way to the answer". I will tell you that I never, ever, solve any sort of math problem without writing it down. Ever.What you need to do is begin by first writing down the problem. Then you begin to solve it one step at a time. Write down even the simple things. What you need to ensure is that every single step that you write down is perfectly legal. In other words, if you are solving an equation for example and you subtract "10" from both sides....write that down. Then in the NEXT step actually do that subtraction. Then if you need to divide both sides by "2" write THAT down...then in the NEXT step actually do the division. This gives you a paper trail to check your work and also it allows you to break the problem down in to bite sized chunks. If you can be sure that every single little step is legal, then you will be in good shape. If you try to do too many things at one time, which is common, you will probably try to do something illegal and get into trouble.4)When you study and do homework, try to find a quiet place to do it~I was the worst offender of this while in school. I used to listen to music all of the time while trying to do homework. I'd also listen to the TV as 'background noise" while studying. Over time I realized that if I had a quiet place without the background noise, I could focus much better. What I found is that when reading, for example...I would have to read something perhaps 3 or 4 times if I was listening to something else but only once if I had some quiet. People love to listen to music while studying, but I am convinced that it is much more effective if you don't. Try to find a quiet spot in your home or in the Library to get your schoolwork done and you will get your work done much more quickly because you'll be able to focus and absorb more.5)If someone asks you for help, try to explain the topic to them as best you can~This one is going to seem a little odd for this list...but there is one universal truth. Those who can teach others have a true grasp of the material. Many times when studying in groups there will be one member of the group who is behind and doesn't "get it". Try to help that person, even if your own work will take longer. Not only will you feel like you are helping someone else succeed, but the process of rephrasing information back to someone else and breaking things down into bite sized chunks will increase your own understanding. It will help you understand at a fundamental level what the stumbling blocks are for the topic, which will help you as you move on in your math studies.6)Never, ever work math problems in pen~This one is pretty simple. You will make a mistake; it is only a matter of time. When you do, you will want to completely erase your mistake and write over it. You will never, ever want to scratch something out and write next to the scratch-out. This will lead to a paper that is hard to read, and the scratch-outs will actually increase your anxiety about solving these problems. You want clean-neat paper with a clean well thought-out solution.7)Try to use a mechanical pencil with separate eraser, if you can~This one is pretty simple. You will make a mistake; it is only a matter of time. When you do, you will want to completely erase your mistake and write over it. You will never, ever want to scratch something out and write next to the scratch-out. This will lead to a paper that is hard to read, and the scratch-outs will actually increase your anxiety about solving these problems. You want clean-neat paper with a clean well thought-out solution. Thanks A2A.

REVISED Oct 2015, after notification of article merger  A moment’s searching shows there are already numerous "curriculum" style replies to this question on Quora. Posting one more doesn’t seem to add value, so my answer is intended to focus specifically on the “How”, about which I’ve thought long and hard. IMO: How one can learning maths depends on many things: - How far do you want to go? - enough to attain another goal, or as far as you brain will take you?  Ask yourself why you want to learn math - for pleasure, for university-level pure math, for application in a related subject like economics or engineering, to impress someone,...? (Your approach depends on this) - Ask yourself how you think when trying to learn maths: mainly in images, in purely abstract/symbolic terms (both encouraging signs) or mainly in words (less-good sign - See Jacques Hadamard's book from the 1930s "On the psychology of invention in the mathematical field")?  Or like Einstein, who also "thought with his muscles" (See my New Scientist lettert on this, if you can find it - It's on ResearchGate too) - What time of day are you best able to concentrate on math. For me, it's 5am, when I can't sleep - Don't just "read" math - do it and think about it A LOT, so do examples till you've worn your pencil to a nub, and think about the topics from many angles, especially how one thing can viewed as another, e.g. how a function can be considered as a vector... - When you're stuck, there are many things you can do (this could be the topic for whole new Question, if someone's willing to ask it), --- try easily accessible alternatives such as Wikipedia,** different textbooks, and math-oriented chat-rooms like Stack Exchange (** See further below)--- Do you know anyone who might help you if/when you get so stuck that you're scratching your head till there's brain matter under your fingernails?  - Do you have access to a library (or funds to purchase books) on the topics you're interested in? - Think about what you're studying/obsessing about when you're  not actively engaged in life's essentials: queuing, or trying to get to sleep, or otherwise.--- In particular, as maths educator Arnold Ross used to say                        "Think deeply on simple things" - As most people will recommend: Work progressively, starting with the basics - though it may be inspirational to jump ahead to more ambitious material, try to make sure you feel you understand most of what you're studying before moving ahead - And most of all, enjoy the "click" of understanding - it's almost as good as the other most pleasurable thing in life...  Finally, to add my ha'porth* on the "curriculum aspect": If you want a good elementary starting point, try "What Is Mathematics?: An Elementary Approach to Ideas and Methods" by the late Richard Courant (Author), Herbert Robbins (Author), Ian Stewart (Contributor)" (I've already recommended this on another Quora post). Good luck! * "half-penny-worth" for non-UK readers (i.e. very little) EARLY UPDATE MOVED, OCT 2015, to below original answer.  Relevant bio:I’m not a natural or gifted mathematician – just fascinated by math with a desire to achieve some understanding of mind-bending ideas. I sense that a large proportion of Quora posters are more like me than they are like the PhD mathematicians on Quora.  I started as a PhD chemist, and now, years later, trying to understand betterspinors and Clifford algebras. So I’ve had to struggle (and still do), and as a result I’ve learned some things about “How I learn maths” (plural! I’m from the UK). ** And while I’m on the topic, one closely-related bugbear of mine is that while the WWW enables such fabulous sources for maths and physics as Wikipedia to be, potentially, enormously helpful to the aspiring student (so much better than pre-WWW, when often the only alternative if stuck was to throw the book at the wall), there is a tendency for the posts there to be written by those who are reasonably expert, but who write less to inform those who wish to learn, and rather more to show those who know the subject already how cleverly and succinctly the author can demonstrate their own expertise. Though some entries are improving, many tend to be a lot less helpful than they might be. My ‘solution’ to this problem is therefore to look for additional sources on a topic, and try to piece together what I’m seeking to understand by working between the sources.

Socrates was asked about wisdom. Most expected an answer long and sour, but Socrates kept it short and sweet: “The beginning of wisdom is a DEFINITION of terms.”   I. The DNA of MATHEMATICS  One day Bertrand Russell’s elder brother (Frank) attempted to teach him geometry. Of course, before Frank could even dust off Euclid’s Elements, his precocious little brother had already ignited a protest. “I refuse to accept the axioms!” Russell protested. Frank shook his head in disbelief. “Berty, unless you accept the Euclidean axioms, such as ‘all right-angles are equal to one another,’ why, I’m afraid will never be able to get on with the matter!” Eventually the headstrong youth loosened the cranial vise-grip, thereby allowing them to get on with the matter. Aha! You see:  The “most obvious thing” is the axiom, which must be assumed true in order to get on with it. And in the process of getting on with it, which always comes about “in the least obvious way,” a proof is born! In other words, as Einstein noted, axioms are nothing but “implicit definitions.” And so, the sole function of a proof lies merely in rendering explicit what initially lay implicit. Bingo! To put it simply: every mathematical proof is akin to unpacking an axiomatic suitcase.  For the above reason, the intellectual secret society known as the Cambridge Apostles, best stated the key to learning mathematics as follows:  This “Formal Apostles’ Creed,” so to speak, as championed by the likes of Wittgenstein, sheds light on one of history’s most overlooked “Trinities.” Given that axioms serve as the very DNA of proof, and it lies with the philosopher, ultimately, to clarify such axiomatic assumptions, it’s apparent the key to learning mathematics consists of getting a firm handle on each aspect of the formal triad. “To understand a science,” noted Camus, “it is necessary to know its history.” For the above reasons:   II. The LOGIC of LOGIC and the MATHEMATICS of MATHEMATICS  Frank stressed the point to his younger brother that learning mathematics consists solely of grasping the nature of getting on with it. Indeed, the measure of mathematical rigour lies in the extent to which the rigor mortis has set in on an impending logical skeletal structure. Any unwarranted assumptions in the course of the meticulous step-by-step construction comes at a hefty price. Even Euclid’s Elements—once thought infallible—fell pray to lack of rigour. And here lies the key to learning mathematics. After all, in mathematics there is only one “sin” . . . and that sin is named:  From getting a firm handle on notation down to clearly grasping the axioms at play, the aim is to render a chain of reasoning that’s airtight. In short, think of the axiom as the fertilized egg . . . logic as the process of gestation . . . and the mathematical proof as the entirety of the process—from conception to the birthed theorem that screams: “Q.E.D.”  For the above reason, given the chief function of mathematics (correspondence exhibited between identities), Bertrand Russell rightfully concluded:  The result? For anyone who aspires to learn mathematics it’s vital to have a precise meaning of the axioms and the resultant propositions. After all, every proof—if properly formulated—lends its steps to be retraced back to the self-evident axioms. And given that logic merely employs the transformation rule—to render explicitly evident what lay implicit in the axioms—to allow any vagueness or ambiguity to creep into one’s chain of reasoning is to invite inconsistency. In short, treat the notion of equality relation (A = B), which is the very heart of mathematics, as though you were a blind man using identity for a walking stick.  You can only get off track if you fail to deduce precisely from your axioms. Just unpack the axiom—step-by-step. …  III. In CLOSING  I suppose there’s a reason calculators and painstaking note-taking are synonymous with mathematics. Indeed, where mathematics most notably differs from other disciplines is she requires all her courters to pursue her with patience. After all:  Sure, chess and checkers are played on the same game board, as does mathematics equally partake of the tree of knowledge with all other branches. Chess, however, differs markedly from checkers on the account that its mastery hides in the details. Whereas the checkers player is prone to win the game in one fell swoop and most non-mathematical disciplines paint with the broadest of strokes, the eleventh commandment of mathematics and chess alike is simple: Thou shalt not take anything for granted!  To truly learn mathematics entails never straying from what the axiomatic definitions implicate. After all, what more is a function than the account of how one varying quantity derives from another quantity? x ↦ f (x) What more is a fraction (Latin: fractus, "broken") than the breaking of the whole into equal parts, which initially lay implicit in the original whole? What more is a a ratio than the expressed relationship between two numbers, namely, the indication of how many times the second number lies implicit in the first? Remember, the very DNA of proof—those all-important axioms—is noting but implicit definitions. Starting to notice a theme here? In ancient times those initiated into the mysteries were well-versed in the sacred symbol of mathematics:  After all, just as The Ouroboros is the serpent that eats its own tail, The Proof is the axiom that eats its own theorem! Mathematics is only the art of saying the same thing with different words! For the above reason, when the vaunted Socratic method is finally turned inwardly upon mathematics, what exactly does the ancient Greek roots reveal? Máthēma— "what one gets to know." Bingo! To learn mathematics is merely an exercise in uncovering “what one gets to know.” And just as the father seated in the waiting room while his wife endures labor . . . labor derived from the fertilized axiomatic egg + logical gestation = newborn theorem . . . the proud father for the first time locks eyes on what one gets to know.  The beginning of wisdom is a definition of terms!    DOG fo DNIM ehT

I was exactly like this about 2 years ago.  Then I began studying in a new way. Instead of solving the equations given to me each week and going to class I read through my course literature more carefully. Spending time reading up on the math helped a lot. I tried to draw figures of how things looked. I tried to imagine what would happen if things weren't defined the way they were. I tried to learn what everything represented and the history to why it was represented that way. And most importantly, when I read a proof and they skipped a step in their calculations I did them myself and wrote them in the margin. Every other insight I had I wrote down as well (and drew figures). I made the literature "complete" for my own understanding. And I did it so that if I forgot a week later I could go back and re-check it and memorize it even better. By doing this I understood math way better and my grades improved. When it comes to math you must spend time with why you do each step. And you must also learn that math is a language that we invented to save time. Just as I gave an explanation quite similar to that in  Physics: Is mathematics really necessary for understanding the nature which is tinier and at the same time more massive than I can imagine?  But when you've seen enough math you start to see the beauty in it. That it is an art. Right now though, you need to see the system they (the mathematicians) invented to save time when describing our world. When you've come to this realisation, and really understand the system, then the math will not be as difficult. So take your time with it. And if you really don't grasp certain concepts, check out youtube videos, or google it, or ask us Quora users. We'll help you.  EDIT: I would also like to add that there's a psychological bonus to this. By writing down things we are supposed to remember we feel less pressure to remember it and will relax more. That has the effect that our brain will remember it better. So writing notes for you to remember will actually make your brain relax so much better that you don't need the note and can almost throw it away. Weird right? Yes, but a great trick to use.

There is no "one right way" to do most math problems.  Draw a picture to represent the situation in a word problem (whenever appropriate).  If I'm helping you with math, I can see by your picture whether you understand the concept and did the arithmetic wrong, or whether you have a different idea than I do of what the problem is about. Try to understand the reason for doing things, not just memorize a bunch of formulas or a series of steps (you will have to do some of both). If one way of doing the problems isn't working, try talking to another teacher, going to Khan Academy or a different textbook, etc.  Sometimes one method will you just make more sense to you than another, and as long as you consistently get correct answers in a reasonable amount of time, the method is "right".  Some methods work for a greater range of problems than others; I like these better because I don't have to remember as many different things. Look for strategies to keep the number of digits small (reducing fractions, cross-cancelling, etc.), as this will help reduce arithmetic errors. Model the situation with "easier" numbers.  If I want to check whether something like combinations and permutations is being done correctly (a topic I don't remember too well), I can do an example with 2 or 3 things, and list all the combinations/permutations.  If I get the same answer I get with the formula, I'm probably using the correct formula.  I can check percent problems with 10%, 25%, 50%, 100%. "Ballpark" your answers with "easier" numbers.  If I use the percents above, 3 as an approximation for pi, etc. I can do many simple problems on paper or mentally.  Then when I actually have 48% (instead of 50) or 3.14159 as a value for pi, I know about where my answer should be.  If it's off by a factor of 10 or 100, I may have misplaced a decimal.  If the percent is way off, maybe I've confused multiplication and division.

We learn math by analogy, association, and steps. I will explain in reverse order. Steps: All math beyond the elemental or basics is learned by building on a previous idea/concept. The way I used to explain problem solving to students is that is like trying to get to the second floor from the first floor. If you try to solve a problem all at once that is like jumping from the first floor to the second floor which only a few people in the world can do. But, if you one thing you know then another and another, eventually the problem solves itself. This is like walking up the steps from the first floor to the second floor, which most people can do. Learning a new mathematical concept is easiest when it related to previouslt learned concepts. Association: We take something we know or understand and relate it to a “new” idea or concept. Like relating a swing to a parabola. Analogy: Using imagination to relate a “story” or relationship to an idea. For instance when we are first learning to count, we use objects like fingers and blocks to assign the idea of “number” to how many fingers or blocks there are. Learning math is a process which is more about learning how to think than it is about manipulating numbers. Higher level mathematics is less about numbers and more about “relationships.” For instance topology is more about relationships of shapes, ie. a square, a circle, and a triangle are topologically equivalent because you can “bend” or “stretch” the boundary to make the others. But a doughnut is not because it has two boundaries.

You can't do anything efficiently without clearly articulating why you are doing it.  If you don't have a goal you can't know whether you are making progress toward it. Learning math isn't really a goal.  There's too much.  You could spend your entire life learning math and still not know anything of any use for what you wanted to learn math for.  Really, to learn math efficiently you mostly have to decide what not to learn.  You might find How to Become a Pure Mathematician (or Statistician) useful as a way to understand generally what areas of mathematics tend to be learned and what order they come in. So, if you want to learn math to apply it in some way, then that's one thing.  If it's science then that's different from philosophy which is different from psychology which is different from computer programming.  Get specific.  But for any of these you'll want to learn math as a tool, and to be efficient you can leave out pretty much all the things related to proofs.  That's a big deal.  And which things you pick lets you leave out huge swaths of mathematics that aren't useful for those things.  For example if you want math for computer programming you'll learn graph theory and logic but eschew complex analysis and topology. If you want to learn math just because it's wonderful and makes you happy, then you're probably talking more about pure mathematics.  That's more work because it's the proofs that are the heart of things: so less practice using the tool but lots more time understanding what it is and how it works.  The only way to be efficient about this is to figure out what sorts of math make you happiest and concentrate on those.  To some extent the logicians, analysts, and algebraists all get to ignore the details of the other areas. Lastly, if you want to learn math just to impress people, then you can be really efficient.  Learn a few calculation tricks and stay away from actual mathematicians.  Pretty soon you'll learn that knowing math doesn't actually impress anybody (except mathematicians) and you'll be done.

Most of my mathematics education has been informal; I took a few upper division math courses during undergrad (linear algebra and two differential equations courses) but have also read quite a few books on various topics on my own. Often while delving into a subject, though, I would read through books fairly quickly without spending a lot of time on the exercises which would result in a fairly superficial understanding of the material. How, then, should one study mathematics? Start at the Bottom Often you may find yourself wanting to learn an advanced topic for whatever reason and it can be tempting to want to drive straight in. Unfortunately, if you do not meet the prerequisites for that subject, then any attempts to learn it will be mostly fruitless. My first experience with linear algebra was an attempt at self learning. At the time, I did not know that undergraduate mathematics had two levels of linear algebra (lower division computational and upper division proof based) and ultimately failed trying to learn from Shilov’s book. Be patient. Fundamentals may be mundane but they are important. Work Slowly Right now I am reading Lieb and Loss’s Analysis. I am on chapter 1 and have been for a little while. Why? I don’t find measure/integration theory to be very intuitive. What do sigma-algebras have to do with measurability? It can be tempting to want to move on to a new topic before you have attained a full understanding of the current topic and care needs to be taken to ensure that this doesn’t happen. If you are not comfortable with how the formal definition of something is related to the intuitive notion (e.g. what open sets have to do with deformability in topology), then you are probably not ready to move past that topic. Read Actively Not all textbooks have exercises with solutions (in fact, not all textbooks even have exercises), but few (if any) are lacking in theorems with their proofs given as part of the main text. When you come across a solved example or a theorem and a proof while reading a textbook, take it as an exercise, not a passage to be read passively. Being able to do the proofs will test your knowledge of the material. Even if you can’t do the entire proof without the guidance of the textbook, actively working through it while you follow along will lead to a better understanding than simply reading the proof. Bring Abstract Concepts Down to Earth As math becomes more abstract and formal it becomes much more difficult to comprehend the meaning and significance of the theorems and definitions that you are presented with. One of the most important tools for understanding abstract mathematics is to be able to connect these concepts to specific examples that you are already familiar with. Once you have found such an example, see if you can figure out how it relates to the abstract concept and after that try to find different examples that illustrate how, exactly, this new concept is in fact more general than the one that you are familiar with. Supplement Definition/Theorem/Proof Style Textbooks Many textbooks place the responsibility of connecting formal definitions with intuition on you. If you are not comfortable with this style of teaching or feel that you could use some assistance, don’t hesitate to consult another resource. Quora and StackExchange are two such resources where students of mathematics often come in search of motivation for mathematical theorems and definitions. If you are feeling particularly confident, then you can take a stab at answering some questions yourself (even your own questions); if there were any doubts in your mind about your understanding of a topic before answering a question about it, they should be mostly gone by the time you’ve finished constructing a clear and carefully constructed response. Take a Formal Course Self teaching is difficult. If you can, take courses in the subjects that you care the most about. In a formal course, you will have mandatory assignments and deadlines which will force you to stay focused and to practice. You will also have an instructor, a TA, and a group of peers to act as a support group as you work through the material.

Understanding how you approached the problem and where you went wrong is a great way of becoming stronger and avoiding the problems Do not try to memorise the processes.This is counter-productive. I’m quoting the answer that I wrote in Nicholas Cooper's answer to What is mathematics? because I think that it’s relevant here. No one definition could or should work. The reason is that what mathematics is like a camera, giving different answers depending on the focus. Instead, it should be intuitively understood in various levels: At a very intuitive level, by abstracting the notion of “game” philosophically, mathematics can be thought of as the study of “rules for games, and how those games can play out”.At the most formal fundamental level, mathematics is the study of “virtual structures created from premises, and the logical consequences of those premises”. In this way, it is the study of logic, and it shares some amazingly important similarities to programming (software development). When people speak of a “language of mathematics” they are talking about the similarities that it has to a programming language.At the next level, once relations are defined, mathematics could be said to be the study of “relationships between things”. It’s important to note that, by studying relationships, one can derive logic systems again (even new ones). More importantly, this definition imparts the notion that there are connections far-and-wide between different areas of mathematics.At the next level, once relationships can be used to describe value, mathematics could be said to be the study of “value, structure, and change”. This recognizes that even shapes can be classified as structure, functions can be classified as values, and that computation can actually fall under change.At another level yet (and perhaps the most inexact here), one can say that mathematics is the study of computation.All of this is defined without reference to numbers, because value may be important, but quantity is not necessary when talking about mathematics, and quantity arises often due to the connectivity of mathematics, but not often enough to even mention it as being something mathematics is about. Others here have describe mathematics as a language. That is not 100% correct, but it’s understandable why people say as much. It’s more like a programming language, with various syntaxes described by humans, but semantics that are all its own (Nicholas Cooper's answer to Does mathematics possess its own syntax and semantics?).

Step one: Learn the basics of a concept. Step two: ask yourself, “What can I do with this concept? Step three: consider the concept in that light for a minute. Just give it a good think. Step four: solve a bunch of problems so that you have mastered use of the topic. Step five: Repeat for the next topic. Step six: Go back and compare what you did do to what you thought in step two. How did your predictions compare to what was actually the next topic covered? If they were the same, great! You understood the original concept. If not, why did it differ? Can you solve your original question, and if not, what else do you need? This last step is a sort of self-assessment which you should run on every topic - it’s easy to “convince yourself you understand something,” but unless you can use it (and not only to solve the mostly-algorithmic problems you find in your textbook!), you don’t understand it well enough, and that will mess you up down the line.

Learning mathematics is similar in many ways to learning a language. You start by learning some basic vocabulary, and pretty soon you are putting together statements that have some meaning. In mathematics you learn some basic vocabulary in elementary school. Oh, yes, there’s the basic arithmetic facts, but along with 3 + 5 = 8, you are also learning what the operation of addition means. The equals sign is the verb in that statement saying the left side has the same value as the right. The next step up the ladder, algebra, requires developing an abstract understanding of the arithmetic operations. A key idea is that solving an equation is just a matter of undoing the operations that have been done to an unknown number. If the equation is x – 7 = 12 you know that if you subtract seven from the unknown number you get twelve. So if you undo the subtract seven, you would know what x is. Since x – 7 = 12 is a true statement (if they are lying to you, you wouldn’t know anything anyway), undo the subtract seven by adding seven to both sides—like keeping a teeter totter in balance. Yes, there is a tad bit more to algebra than that, but that is the glorious part about mathematics. The rest of it is just a matter of learning pesky details. My point is that mathematics is an interrelated structure of abstract ideas. Learning about abstract ideas is not building fairy castles in the sky. The principles of mathematics are the tools for understanding the universe. (The why of that relationship is an interesting philosophical question in itself.) Be sure not to let all the details of the computational complexities blind you to the overall simplicity of the abstract ideas behind them. Ask yourself, what do I have to do—and why?

A practical way to learn mathematics that worked for me, is to learn about basic circuit theory. Learn Ohm's Law, Kirchhoff's Current Law (KCL) and Kirchhoff's Voltage Law (KVL). Get a breadboard with binding posts or 'banana plugs', a cheap DMM, a 4 x AA battery holder, a pack of AA batteries, a bunch of 1 watt metal film resistors, say from 1000 (1k) Ohms to 10000 (10k) Ohms. Measure each resistor's Resistance value R Ohms, and write the value down. Connect up each resistor to the battery, measure the voltage across it, then measure the current through it. Start with Ohm's Law:Write down V = I*R Volts (the * symbol means to multiply; this is used by computer interpreters or compilers to multiply two numbers together, as well as Applications Software such as Microsoft Excel), from the measured value of the current, multiply it with each resistance value, then compare the calculated voltage with the measured voltage; there will be a small difference due to the measurement error that is inherent to the DMM's design, but that is OK, as along as you're within the % error of the measurement error of the DMM, as given in the DMM's manual in the specifications.Divide R to both sides of V = I*R, i.e. V/R = I*R/R reducing to V/R = I Amps or as some people prefer I = V/R Amps, then divide the measured voltage by the Resistance value. Next, you may try to calculate the Power dissipated by the Resistor, starting with P = V*I Watts, then calculate the power rating of the resistor by using the measured voltage and current values. Then by substituting first I = V/R Amps, into P = VI = V*V/R Watts, or P = (V^2) / R Watts (the ^ symbol in computer language means to raise to the power of; some compilers or interpreters use **). Another learning vehicle, may be to calculate the Power dissipated by the Resistor, starting again with P = V*I Watts, then substituting V = I*R Volts, into P = V*I = I*R*I = (I^2)*R Watts. Then plug in each measured value of current into I, squaring it, then multiplying by plugging in the measured resistance value R. Kirchhoff's Voltage Law and Kirchhoff's Current Law require constructing resistor networks, and deriving simultaneous equations, for solving for the unknowns. The above may be a non-tedious way to learn basic algebra, and see how algebra has practical applications.

Unlike some other subjects, Mathematics is not simply a collection of facts to be memorized. Computational math does require memorization of rules, and practice. There is no way to avoid that. (i.e. numbers, sets, symbols,etc.)The subsets of objects with similar character. (integers, rationals, reals,etc.)The defined operations among the objects. (addition, etc.)The rules that define the behavior of the objects. (Associativity, commutativity, etc.)Perform the defined operations on the objects of interest until you are comfortable that you have achieved the desired level of competence. Move on to the next topic. Mathematics beyond computation is a symbolic classification system. Axioms are derived from the classifications, and logic is applied to them to produce new results in the system. Making such logical extensions takes much experience with abstract mathematical systems. This usually requires expert guidance to achieve mastery.

To quote a well known math person to a royal person who asked the same question as this, “There is no royal road to geometry.” Of course, math people will know the famous math person, but I think the quote itself is sufficient to say there is no “easier” way to learn math than another. There might be some things a person can do to make the experience less stressful, but most people learn math in about the same manner. Examples; Person A and person B are learning the same math. Say, in the first example, arithmetic. Person A learns that 1 + 1 = 2. Person A doesn’t really have any particular tangential “real world” reference. Such as, if I have an apple and increase this with another apple, then we say I have two apples. This has a little more meaning to the person that just saying 1 + 1 is 2, but you would probably be hard pressed to find someone who didn’t have that kind of a visual idea in mind. Set ahead in mathematics to calculus. It is easier to find people who do not have applicable understanding of concepts at this level. Take a relatively “simple” derivative. For the function f(x) = x^2 (x squared) the derivative fprime(x) = 2x is known by most people who have studied calculus. However, if you have not studied calculus, then you would not know that, and you don’t have much context to place this in. If someone then asks what is the derivative of x^3 one might stumble on the right answer, but stumbling on the derivative on the function sin(x) is unlikely. To understand its derivative if one understand the underneath concept then they simply compute the answer with the underlying concept. Otherwise they struggle. So, one might think there is an “easier” way to “learn” calculus, but unfortunately there is not.

Mathematics is a subject that every student has to study at one time or another. Some love it but if we’re being honest, most people hate studying maths. The importance of maths for students has never been more prominent. Most university courses include some level of maths while almost every profession uses maths in some form on a daily basis. The problem many students have is that they don’t know how to study maths to get good results. Maths is one of those subjects which you can easily spend hours studying but end up none the wiser. However much you have studied, if you can not solve the problem on day of the test, you are lost. Thankfully, there are some techniques for studying maths that you can do regardless of your level. 7 Tips for Maths Problem Solving 1. Practice, Practice & More Practice It is impossible to study maths properly by just reading and listening. To study maths you have to roll up your sleeves and actually solve some problems. The more you practice answering maths problems, the better. Each problem has its own characteristics and it’s important to have solved it in numerous ways before tackling the exam. There is no escaping this reality, to do well in a Maths exam you need to have solved a LOT of mathematical problems beforehand. 2. Review Errors When you’re practising with these problems, it’s important to work through the process for each solution. If you have made any mistakes, you should review them and understand where your problem-solving skills let you down. Understanding how you approached the problem and where you went wrong is a great way of becoming stronger and avoiding the same mistakes in the future. 3. Master the Key Concepts Do not try to memorise the processes. This is counter-productive. It is much better and rewarding in the long-run to focus on understanding the process and logic that is involved. This will help you understand how you should approach such problems in the future. Remember that Maths is a sequential subject so it’s important to have a firm understanding of the key concepts that underpin a mathematical topic before moving on to work on other, more complex solutions which are based on understanding the basics. 4. Understand your Doubts Sometimes you can get stuck trying to solve part of a maths problem and find it difficult to move on to the next stage. It’s common for many students to skip this question and continue on to the next. You should avoid doing this and instead spend time trying to understand the process of solving the problem. Once you have grasped an understanding of the initial problem, you can use this as a stepping stone to progress to the remainder of the question. Remember: Maths requires time and patience to master. It is a good idea to study with a friend who you can consult with and bounce ideas off when trying to solve complex problems. 5. Create a Distraction Free Study Environment Mathematics is a subject that requires more concentration than any other. A proper study environment and a distraction free area could be the determining factor when solving complex equations or problems in geometry, algebra or trigonometry! Studying with music can help create a relaxing atmosphere and stimulate the flow of information. Having suitable background music can foster an environment of maximum concentration. Of course, you should steer clear of Pitbull and Eminem, instrumental music is the best thing in these times. 6. Create a Mathematical Dictionary Mathematics has specific terminology with a lot of vocabulary. We suggest you create Notes or Flashcards with all the concepts, terminology and definitions you need to know. You should include their meanings, some key points and even some sample answers so you can consult them at any time and recap. 7. Apply Maths to Real World Problems As much as possible, try to apply real-world problems when approaching maths. Maths can be very abstract sometimes so looking for a practical application can help change your perspective and assimilate ideas differently. Probability, for example, can be used in everyday life to predict the outcome of something happening and determine whether you want to take a risk such as if you should buy a lottery ticket or gamble. Oh and don’t forget that it’s also important to have confidence in yourself and face the exam knowing that you have prepared properly!

This is an interesting question. When I was coming up (taught under the old-school model of algorithmic memorization with little concept), I struggled horribly with math. Back-in-the-day, all I knew was that I didn’t learn math in the same way I did everything else, which I excelled it — even science (until numbers came up). I was (and always have been) good at memorizing basic math facts, formulas, and even long series of numbers (i.e. multiplication tables, the Quadratic Formula, bank acct. numbers, debit/credit card into and such). The thing that caused me to suck at math was the algorithmic memorization (mostly). I couldn’t remember algorithms I didn’t understand. I’m the kind of person that needed to be taught (and understand) something like the Distributive Property BEFORE being introduced to the standard algorithm of multiplication. I work my way through problems, relying heavily on number relationships and mathematical concepts and logic. My brain doesn’t just jump to a standard simply because it exist. Speaking of which, I tend to prefer to do problems outside of the standard algorithms. Part of this stems from the fact that I don’t view numbers as digits — but for what the numbers represent, if that makes sense. I need to see things in expanded form FIRST in order to transition to “shortcut” methods. I also like to diagram problems and use Area Models and things of this sort. I’m that person that prefers to add to solve a subtraction problem (or typically sees them as positive and negative numbers on a number line) or that views a division problem through the lens of multiplication. If you were to ask me what 255/5 is, I would think, “5 X what = 255”? It depends on the problem and context. I’ve also found that video REALLY quickens the rate at which I learn things. Finally, I would say that I view math as a language (the language of numbers). With the way my brain processes things, I really see no difference between a traditionally-spoken language or even a gestural language like American Sign Language. They are all just different ways to communicate.

I think the answer is paradoxical: you must go more slowly to learn more quickly. Mathematical mastery (to whatever level you would like to reach) is a large undertaking. The same is true for math.  Go slowly and master one small step, then go on to the next one.  If you try to jump ahead or race through the fundamentals, you will find yourself confused at one point or another -- and if you try to force your way through a concept rather than backing up and learning the more basic concepts that lead to that point, you will find that confusion becoming exponential. For methodology, you could do a lot worse than signing onto Khan Academy and just doing whatever is the next exercise they recommend, for the rest of your life.  Start with their "counting to ten" exercise and just work forward until you find something difficult -- then look at hints and watch the videos (and use any outside source you like) until it's no longer difficult, then continue.  It's not fast, but it's *thorough*, and without that, you'll have nothing.

I recommend the following four stages for effective learning, without compromising on the quality (1 and 2 are obvious, but I have to mention): Understanding the concepts: Do not spend too much time on the theory, although this step is absolutely essentialUsing the concepts: Solve basic numericals involving single concepts (one for each concept), and then a combination of several concepts to understand their interplay.Contemplate: Look through the concepts and the numericals again, and mark/highlight the things you might forget.Formulate: Having done 1–3, put yourself in the shoes of someone designing examination questions. Write down stuff that you might want to ask to test a thorough understanding of the concepts and applications. (This step may require several references and more understanding, which is the purpose of this exercise).The above may seem to take more time than usual, but it reduces the time and effort substantially when practiced (not to mention the quality of understanding requiring little revision later).
